tr.td: Bororo South America Brazil Bororoan Bororoan SOV three demonstratives indicating distance from the speaker ergative/absolutive distinction in agreement 1;1 not clearly described by Crowell. Given that 3sg prefix (inalienable possession) can be omitted, it's impossible to tell on the basis of the existing examples. A telling case could be plural possessor, or optionally possessed nouns 2;2 3;3 house brother (elder) brother (yonger) food wife knife foot nose tooth name thing ornament pet not_found The same prefix is used to mark agreement on the verb with subjects, objects. Crowell1979 calls it "bound pronoun" i- a- u-/Ø pa- xe- ta- e- Ino-ba a-wai-re? how-Q 2sg-house-neutral How (big) is your house? Crowell1979:217 i-wiaja 1sg-ear my ear Nonato2008:51 not_found Only the allienable strategy is possible if possessed is elided not_possible Crowell1979:217 money pan stone chicken dog horse fish fish canoe i- a- u-/Ø pa- xe- ta- e- There are differences between descriptions. Crowell1979 analyzed alienable constructions separately from possession of domestic animals According to Nonato 2008, in all those cases we are dealing with classifiers. o ke aku imo Bororo has four classifiers: -ke, used for food items, -aku, used for domesticated animals, -imo, for nouns referring to adornments, and the general classifier -o, used for all other referents. These same markers can also be used alone, receiving a nominal meaning: `food', `pet', `ornament', `thing' in-o ika 1s-thing canoe my canoe Nonato2008:62 in-agu karo 1s-domestic fish My fish (pet) Nonato2008:61 ta-ke karo 2p food fish Your fish (food) Nonato2008:61 My glossess, in spirit of Nonato 2008; Example from Crowell1979:217, he analyzed "akagu" as one morpheme A-k-agu kogariga u-re inagu bi-të 2sg-?-domestic chicken 3sg-neutral 1sg-???-domestic die-causative your chicken killed mine Crowell1979:217 My glossess; Example from Crowell1979:217, he analyzed "ako" as one morphem e-rɨdɨ-re a-k-o tori-ji 3pl-see-neutral 2sg-?-allienable stone-referent They saw your stone Crowell1979:217 not_found Ino-ba a-wai-re? In-o kuri-re how-Q 2sg-house-neutral? 1sg-alienable big-neutral How big i your house? Mine (house) is big. Crowell1979:217 Imedɨ u-tu-re Jose u-wai-të man 3sg-go-neutral Jose 3sg-house-to A man went to Jose's house Crowell1979:217(20) Creusa-re Kadagare onaregediɨ rema Creusa-neutral Kadagare child equative Creusa is Kadagare's child Crowell1979:41(43) Bia paga-re Teodoro batarɨ bogai listen-neutral Teodoro word purpose He listened to Teodoro's words Crowell1979:187(144) not_found not_found My glossess; example from Crowell1979:82 (49) Jose ∅-aku kowaru rekodu-re Jose 3sg-domestic horse run-neutral Jose's horse ran Crowell1979:82 not_found not_found Adyghe Eurasia Russia Northwest Caucasian Northwest Caucasian SOV leg hand back face blood skin organs brother son sister daughter root (of a tree) soul name Complexity is not clear! Gorbunova 2009 analyses the marker as alternation: "sǝ-/s-" (one morpheme). RogavaKershava analyze it as two morphemes: person-number marker "s" and the marker of inalienable possession "ǝ". sǝ- / s-, z- w- / p-, b- ǝ- tǝ-/ t-, d- ŝǝ- / ŝ- a-/ a- se sǝ-ŝha je-s-e-ʁe-wǝzǝ-ž'ǝ I 1sg.pr-head obl-1sg.a-dyn-caus-hurt-re I am making my head hurt (I am breaking my head) Gorbunova:150 not_found not_found muscles son daughter wife husband not_found sǝ- / s-, z- w- / p-, b- ǝ- tǝ-/ t-, d- ŝǝ- / ŝ- a-/ a- -jǝ- allienability marker, according to Gorbunova. Rogava suggests alternation between two prefixs, without splitting alienable into two parts (then the amount o morphemes is the same) s-jə-ləpce-xe-r wəzə-ʁe-x-ep 1sg.pr-poss-muscle-pl-abs hurt-pst-pl-neg my muscles were not hurt Gorbunova:156 my glossess; example from Nikolaeva2012 s-jə-awsˇ ’ale som-jə-sˆ e gwere de-lə-sˇ ’t my-al-wallet rubl-LNK-100 some LOC-lie-AUX There is about 100 rubles in my wallet. Nikolaeva2012 not_found not_found sǝ- / s-, z- w- / p-, b- ǝ- tǝ-/ t-, d- ŝǝ- / ŝ- a-/ a- ??? Not clear to me. It seems that the pronoun attaches to another pronoun??? Needs further investigation Mə uner ŝǝ-oŝəuij this house 2pl.pr-yours this house is yours Rogava1966:89 sǝda ade ŝǝ-oŝəuje-xe-r ara jeŝǝoxerer ??? ??? 2pl.pr-yours-pl-nom ??? ??? well, are yours having fun (are those that belong to you having fun?) Rogava1966:89 3 singular ǝ- 3 plural a-/ a- This is Ergative case marker on the possessor -m This is Ergative case marker on the possessor zǝgerem ha-m ǝ-ŝha-ŝ'tǝ-ʁe-r ǯǝ se s-je-ŝha once dog-erg 3sg.pr-head-aux-pst-abs now I 1sg.pr-poss-head what used to be the dog's head is now my head (note the allienable possession marking in "my head") Gorbunova:153 not_found not_found 3 singular ǝ- 3 plural a-/ a- This is Ergative case marker on the possessor -jǝ- ???allienability marker? or is there indeed an alternation, as Rogava suggests??? then the amount o morphemes is the same -m This is Ergative case marker on the possessor my glossess, Nikolaeva2012:23 se aslan ∅-jə-kart-(*er) s-leʁwə-ʁ I Aslan his-al-photo-(*ABS) 1SG.A-see-PST I saw Aslan’s photo (a/the photo of Aslan) Nikolaeva2012:23 not_found not_found Gorbunova, Rogava1966, Nikolaeva2012 not_found not_found Plains Cree North America Canada Algic Algonquian VSO and VOS (‘theme signs’ is used when the proximate acts on the obviative) none -im a marker of disjoint reference; distribution of -im is unclear (see Wolfart 1973 for discussion) yes 1;1 2;2 hand jaw head mother For detransitivisation Kinship terms are transformed into Impersonal verbs ^oht^awim^aw o-oht^awiy -im -^a -w 3-father.NDA-DISJ-IMP-3 a father Muhlbauer2007 For detransitivisation body parts receive prefix mi- mit^apska up-jaw.NDI a jaw Muhlbauer2007 shue ni- ki- o- ni-...-inan ki-...-inaw ki-...-iwaw o-...-iwaw o-ôsisim-a 3-grandchild.NDA-OBV …his grandchildren ni-stikwân 1-head.NDI my head Muhlbauer2007 not_found not_found sg 3 o- pl 3 o-...-iwaw 3 person pronoun not_found not_found not_found Guajiro South America Colombia Venezuela Caribbean Arawakan Arawakan verb-initial with a preference for VSO order Adelaar2004:157 (based on Alvarez1994: 125) There is a set of relationalstems that function as oblique case markers 1;1 2;2 not_found; consult origianl paper for more detail not_found; consult origianl paper for more detail eye arm father-in-law brother not_found mother head pain hammock profit cleaning thing uncle/chief servant/slave parenthood words child name ranch ta- wa- pɨ- hɨ- nɨ- na- hɨ-/sɨ- a- Adelaar2004: 120 (based on Alvarez1994: 87) ta-ye: 1P.SG-tongue my tongue Adelaar2004:120 not_found not_found machete sling clothing, jewelry rooster hen cloth cup, bowl cantaloupe ta- wa- pɨ- hɨ- nɨ- na- hɨ-/sɨ- a- -se/-si The exact meaning of the suffixes is unclear Adelaar2004:120 (based on Alvarez1994:67) ta-kulu:t-se 1P.SG-cloth-RL my cloth Adelaar2004:120 not_found not_found fish goat ta- wa- pɨ- hɨ- nɨ- na- hɨ-/sɨ- a- -ni the exact meaning of the suffix is uncear not_found not_found spoon knapsack watermelon ta- wa- pɨ- hɨ- nɨ- na- hɨ-/sɨ- a- -ya the exact meaning of the suffix is uncear not_found not_found not_found Adelaar2004 (based on Alvarez1996:31) nɨ-ši kami:ru 3P.SG.MS-father Camilo Camilo's father Adelaar2004 a-tunku-ši kami:rɨ? hu-luʔu tɨ sɨi-ka-lɨ ZP-sleep-S.MS Camilo 3P.FE-inside the.FE hammock.DF.FE Camilo sleeps in the hammock. (lit. inside it's hammock) Adelaar2004 not_found not_found Adelaar p.c. based on Alvarez1996 nu-kulu:t-se Lu:ka 3.SG-clothes-RL Luka Lucas’s clothes Adelaar p.c. not_found not_found no data found; proably a compound not_found alijurm pia creole house Creoles house Alvarez1996:25 not_found not_found Toba South America Paraguay Argentina South Guaicuruan Guaicuruan Word order in Toba is relatively free. In transitive clauses, SVO predominates, andin intransitive clauses VS. Possessors tend to follow possessed elements. not_found not_found 1;1 hypothetically 2;2 but no examples found foot head heart blood mucous wrinkle louse feaver cold cough mother aunt grandfather word shadow footprint portrait name dream soul thinking ornament poncho bracelet housing items violin drum barge spear spindle nostrils (holes) lips (edges) I couldn't find an example in Messineo2003 not_found The indefinite possession or 4th person are indicated by the prefix / n / This strategy is possible only if the holder is a person or an animated reference. i- qad- ʔad- qad-...-i l- ya-teʔe 1pos-mother my mother Messineo2003:129 Adelaar2004 (based on Messineo2000:137) ya-pia-te 1P.SG-leg-D my two legs (dual) Adelaar2004 not_found not_found sombrero shovel car church faith ax earth house tattoo pot guinea pigs uncle eyebrow moon sun wind thunder i- qad- ʔad- qad-...-i l- isomorphism of this marker with the "average verbal score". The relationship between active and passive verbsmedia also implies a higher degree of differentiation of the roles of the participants inconcerning the reciprocal and reflexive verbs. In fact, the average participant instigated, executed and controlled action that so intimately involved (Cf Mithun, 1991: 535). Similarly, the holder of aconstruction marker alienability / n / participant assumes an agent mustperform the action of acquiring the possessed for their own benefit. -n- Messineo: allienable possession marker; interesting isomorphism with some verbal morphology; check 132 Interestingly, he indefinite possession or 4th person is indicated by the prefix / n /. Maybe it is the same marker. That would make Toba similar to Witsuwit'en The actual pronunciation is ɲadoʔo, so we don't see the difference in the amount of morphology i-n-adoʔo 1pos-al-sombrero my sombrero Messineo2003:134 not_found not_found cow horse dog i- qad- ʔad- qad-...-i l- -lo only one classifier, for domestic animals ha-na i-lo wa:ka fem-D 1pos-Clg cow my cow Messineo2003:136 not_found not_found na la-woGo na lwaGayD 3pos-flower D creeperThe flower of the creeperMessineo2000:132 so la-qaya so ya-teʔe D 3pos-brother D 1pos-mother The brother of my mother (lit .: 'brother my mother') Messineo2000:132 not_found not_found Adelaar2004; Messineo2003 not_found not_found not_found not_found Adelaar; Messineo2003 not_found not_found not_found not_found Awa Pit South America Columbia Barbacoan Barbacoan ??? not_found not_found not_found 1;1 but maybe there are more strategies house not_found not_found Awa Pit has distinct pronoun inventories for subject, object/beneficiary and possessor. Awa Pit pronouns (based on Curnow 1997: 86, 94) a-p u-p ro- payn a A plural possessor is either indicated by means of the corresponding singular form, or by the plural nominative. Nominative 1sg "na" 1pl "au" ap yal 1.G house my house Adelaar2004:148 Curnow 1997: 124 see also Curnow 1997:124 au yal we house our house Adelaar2004:148 not_found not_found pig not_found not_found -pa The genitive case marker of Awa Pit coincides with conservative Quechua dialects in two of its allomorphs (-pa, -p) Adelaar2004:146, based Curnow 1997: 124–5 santos-pa kužu santos-gen pig Santos’s pig Adelaar2004:146 not_found not_found Ayacucho Quechua South America Peru Quechuan Quechuan SOV not_found not_found not_found 1;1 the genitive marker on the pronoun is the same as the genitive marker on a nominal possessor. house not_found not_found qam not_found Person agreement on the possessed -ki -n -pa The genitive marker on the possessor qam-pa wasi-ki you-G house-2P your house Adelaar2004:214 not_found not_found house not_found not_found Person agreement on the possessed -ki -n -pa The genitive case marker occurs on the dependent (possessor) member of a possessive construction JOSE CAMACHO, LILIANA PAREDES and LILIANA SÄNCHEZ: The genitive clitic and the genitive construction in Andean Spanish runa-pa wasi-n man-G house-3P a person’s house Adelaar2004:214 kuntur-pa chaki-n condor-GEN leg-3pSG the condor's leg CAMACHO:142 Juan-pa mama-n Juan-GEN mother-3SG Juan's mother CAMACHO: 144 not_found not_found Turkish Eurasia Turkey Cyprus Turkic Altaic SOV not_found not_found not_found (genitive on the possessor, person-number clitic on the possessed)2;1 (person-number clitic on the possessed)1;3 (non-canonical)4;5 3;2 (familiarity-like construction) book not_found -ım kitab-ım masa-da book-1sg table-loc My book is on the table Kamali, p.c. not_found not_found book not_found ben sen on biz siz onlar These clitics mark agreement, also on nouns used predicatively? -ım (n)In: -(n)ın, -(n)in, -(n)un, -(n)ün... -im (1st person, sg and pl) Genitive case, the vovel undergoes vovel harmony Ben-im kitab-ım masa-da 1sg.poss book-1sg table-loc My book is on the table Kamali, p.c. not_found not_found leg cup grocery aunt mother (valide) brother (berodar) husband wife ben sen on biz siz onlar biz-im kız-laz 1pl girl-pl our girls (daughters) Kamali, p.c. not_found not_found -im/-in Genitive case ki The same lexical item appears in relative clauses. many discussions aout its nature not_found Ben-im-ki masa-da 1sg.poss-rel table-loc Mine is on the table Kamali, p.c. sg u pl 3 possessive pronoun -im/-in Genitive case Bilgisayor-ın kablos-u masa-da computer-gen cable-3sg table-loc Computer cable is on the table not_possible Kamali, p.c. not_possible Kamali, p.c. book not_found -im/-in Genitive case Lena-nın kitab masa-da Lena-gen book table-loc Lena's book is on the table not_found not_found not_found not_found Bilgisayor kablos-u masa-da computer cable-3sg table-loc Computer cable is on the table not_found not_found (n)In: -(n)ın, -(n)in, -(n)un, -(n)ün... Genitive case, the vovel undergoes vovel harmony Bu kitab Lena-nın dem book Lena-gen This book is Lena's Kamali; p.c. not_found (n)In: -(n)ın, -(n)in, -(n)un, -(n)ün...
